title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — In the suffocating pressure of a 1990s Eastern Conference playoff war, where every possession was a battle and points were a precious commodity, Reggie Miller didn’t just score. He authored a masterpiece of sheer will.

Miller, the Indiana Pacers’ legendary sharpshooter, delivered a historic 47-point explosion to lift his team to a grueling 87-80 victory over the rival New York Knicks in 1998. On a night where the final score looked more like a halftime total, Miller’s output was a stunning anomaly, a one-man offensive symphony in a defensive dirge.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Miller’s night. While his Pacers teammates struggled to find a rhythm, Miller was a flurry of motion, running defenders through a maze of screens before rising with his iconic, high-release jumper. He was relentless, pouring in points from every angle—the inevitable three-point daggers, slashing drives, and a perfect 12-of-12 from the charity stripe.

The Knicks, known for their own brand of defensive brutality, threw everything they had at him. It didn’t matter. Miller’s 47 points didn’t just lead all scorers; they nearly outscored the entire Pacers bench and accounted for over half of Indiana’s total output. It was a performance that transcended the game, a testament to a singular talent who could seize a moment and bend it to his will.

In a series defined by blood, sweat, and hatred, Reggie Miller provided the artistry. On this night, the final score was almost a footnote. The story was number 31, a solitary force who refused to let his team lose.
